comments.commentBody: Puzzling. The NYT, supported largely by advertising, has an editorial complaining about people spending lots of money on advertising.

This will not stand. And the longer we wait for the correction the greater the risk of violence.
Laws and governance must mirror public opinion, as the population becomes both less conservative and less religious those running the country risk anarchy if they ignore those facts.
A little late for this analysis.  It's never too late for this paper to say it erred in backing Clinton and twisting the news in her favor.  History will not be kind here to the New York Times.

"Hillary Clinton... leads the fund-raising pack with a money machine that has sucked in more than $80 million in super PAC support."
And there you have it. Although this statement is buried in the middle of this editorial, the bottom line is Hillary Clinton is exploiting the political money system more than any republican.
When will the press recognize that big money democrats (e.g. Obama, both Clintons, Schumer, etc) are the biggest exploiters of political donations, and their presence in the government ensure that Wall Street will continue to dominate.
I am so sick and tired of big media enabling the big money interests of democrats while downplaying people who are really trying to change the system (i.e. Bernie Sanders).

The corruption in Americsn politics is scandalous. In other countries politicians would go to jail for accepting unlimited contributions. This said, I get tired of elite -bashing in the comments. Every society has an elite ruling class. The trick is to choose your rulers wisely. If you are so stupid as to be seduced by Koch-paid propaganda, whose fault is that? No money in the world would make me vote for Trump or Sanders. So disregard the ads, learn critical thinking, and accept that being 'ordinary' is not an accolade.

A lot of people think this is just media greed, but nothing is as simple as that. Greed, yes. But media isn't where the greed starts. Media is a symptom, not a cause.

Much of media these days is bleeding red ink. Solid news organizations like the Times are good examples. The only "news" media making money do it by selling sensationalism, not news -- they're selling bread and circuses just like ancient Rome. Faux News is a great example. CNN will take something like the Indonesian airline disappearance and grind and grind and grind on it while real news never gets mentioned. But they make money. Independent local news organizations are becoming as rare as white Rhinos.

There used to be quality news available from outlets like Public Radio and Public Television ... but Republicans dragged them into a back alley and knifed them. NPR today is the struggling remnant. It's like a rose trying to grow in a garbage dump.

OWNER media greed is evil. Sheldon Adelson publishes a free news paper in Israel to push the right wing there and just bought the biggest paper in Las Vegas to twist Nevada politics. Rupert Murdoch is making money hoof over claw with Faux News. But they're just specific cases of the cancer of unrestrained capitalism. Murdoch would just as soon murder kittens or steal purses from old ladies if it paid as well.
Billionaire donors to Democrats are 'environmentals', not liberals. Similar Republican donors are conservative, not 'patrons of the arts'.

It has always been possible to buy and sell politicians. At the present time in the United States, the pretence is that the money goes to campaign expenses, and that the voters ultimately decide. How true can this be?

There are districts where campaigning isn't really necessary. What happens to the money in these places? And what distinguishes its payment from outright bribery?

Good article. Interesting no mention of unions monies given to candidates at all levels(president, Congress state and local politicians) Also the thousands of hours of works unions give to the election of their  candidates.

Super Pac created by wealthy donor and unions.    Both have too much influence over elections, especially the unions at the state and local level in NY.   Governor Coumo changed the retirement loophole where union members could put in as much o/t as they could get in the last 3 years of service to inflate their pensions. which is a good thing.    So, mayb there is some hope for the rest of us to have our wishes heard.

As you say in this editorial:  "Much of this money will surely be wasted, further enriching the new breed of fat-cat campaign operatives, and further alienating voters with toxic advertising." Trump's low-budget success to date would seem to be evidence for this possibility.  In addition to enriching campaign operatives, of course, this money must also benefit lobbyists and the media in which ads are placed.

These rich, aging, white Republicans would probably get a better ROI on their dark money by investing these millions in kids and schools.  The PR alone would win them votes.  But that would be wise and kind.  They prefer shrewd.

True to form, the New York Times writes an editorial bemoaning money in politics, up to 9 billion to be spent this campaign season, without once mentioning the only candidate whose primary message has been its corruptive influence and its destruction of our democracy. Oh, they DO mention Clinton, in that she leads the pack in receiving money from "fatcats". But, they say, she has pledged (wink, wink, nudge, nudge) to promote proposals to rein in the runaway money race.

Once again, Clintonistas implore us to rally around the anointed one if only because.....SCOTUS! Well, we are where we are because of both the Republican and Democratic establishment. For crying out loud, Obama nominated a judge who supported Citizens United! Stop preaching fear of SCOTUS every election and stop looking to SCOTUS to save the country.

Getting money out of politics is every bit as important as eliminating slavery or giving women the vote. Those were accomplished through Constitutional amendment and the buying of our democracy can be stopped in the same way, if the people want it. The Supreme Court would, and could, have nothing to say about it.

The idiots running the ads against Strickland in Ohio have really got under my skin. The ads are everywhere. One cannot escape them. They overwhelm TV viewing and just clicking on this website exposed them to me again. There is no way in hell that I would vote for Portman now. Who the hell are the people who financed these ads. Only the Shadow knows.

We are looking at this problem backwards. You are never going to get the money out of politics as long as politicians keep selling influence. If you take away the product that politicians are selling then no one will spend mega bucks on getting them elected. The first order of business is to reform the contracting rules so that the companies that win public bids will be chosen anonymously based on who can deliver the best product for the best price. If politicians were taken out of the equation in contracting they would have nothing to sell. No more bridges to nowhere and airports for no one just to shift public funds to donors.

That is why the Republicans have not been able to come up with a viable candidate. They keep pouring their money trying control local elections, From this pool of fools they believe they can supply the next Republican presidential candidate.
It was bad enough in 2008 with the likes of Rick Perry leading the pack. Remember how funny we thought it was back then? Could not get worse, right?
Now it is 2016 The Republican Party had a field of 17 candidates, and not one of them, not one, (we had a clown bus, because a clown car would not have been big enough) was worth voting for.
More than ever, we have the best government that money can buy.

This is especially disgusting because these amounts of money can solve real problems that American people suffer from like lack of health care, poor education or missing veterans benefits. Instead this money is being used to buy politicians who will enact laws to hurt the people of the country and solidify the control of the corporatist state. It is also worth noting that most of this money was no earned - it was inherited by what has become the titled nobility of the USA. A king is still a king even if you don't call him king.
Citizens United:  the print and media company full-employment act, at least every two years, and especially every four years.

The Republican candidates with the most PAC money lost badly in this election cycle, including Jeb Bush, whose PAC spent in excess of $100 million, but had nothing but single digit poll numbers and distant election finishes to show for that spending. So despite all the hand wringing, this election year has also shown the real limitations of campaign contributions to buy victories.

As for Bernie Sanders and his supporters, who rail against campaign contributions and election laws, neither Sanders not his supporters have had anything to say about the undemocratic nature of caucuses, which have been critical to Sanders' success.

For a candidate who purports to be for the working people, Sanders has no problem with a system that excludes anyone who cannot arrive at a caucus site at a specific time and stay for the many hours necessary to complete the process. In Washington State, only 230,000 Democratic voters were able to participate in the state's caucus, which Sanders won, but over 700,000 participated in the later primary which allowed voting by mail, which Clinton won. So hundreds of thousands of people were excluded from the caucus, and even at this late date neither Sanders nor his supporters have registered any problem with this fact.

So to hear Sander's supporters talk about how Sanders is going to make the system fairer, while he doesn't even recognize his own success depends on an inherently unfair system is a joke.

The more things change, the more they become the same. The current caterwauling of "bought" votes is no different than Landslide Lyndon's 84 vote Senatorial win in Texas courtesy of the Duke of Duval who controlled and spread money around the the barristos in the Southwest District.

The only difference is inflation and Citizens United. It now cost a lot more to buy votes.

Those 268 Members of the House who are reportedly millionaires -- are their annual incomes measured in the millions or is it their net worth? It makes a big difference.

Moral decay sets in when the elected officials begin to enrich themselves at the expense of the public.

Trump is the most blatant psychopath in public life. The way he deflects to "I'm going to build a wall!" every time he is questioned why the judge in the Trump University is allegedly biased against him is the last thing anyone needs in the White House.

Rich people who support Trump should get their own heads examined.

If people across this land truly want more of a "say" in what happens in Washington DC and in their local communities, then I would strongly recommend that they vote Democratic. Then the new Democratic president, with the help and support of a Democratically controlled Senate and House, can choose a Supreme Court justice who can then be the decisive vote in overturning that hideous "Citizens United" decision that has robbed us of our constitutional voice in determining our collective future.

Transparency ! That's what this country needs !

So let's hold an open and public auction for members of congress and maximize the amount that billionaires have to pay for them.

Oh ... wait ... that means that a lot of them would be buying themselves.
